title: Authors and Citation
text: Majumder R, Shaby B, Reich B, Cooley D (2026). BezELS: Bezier splines Estimating Limit Sets. R package version 0.1.0, https://reetamm.github.io/BezELS/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {BezELS: Bezier splines for Estimating Limit Sets},   author = {Reetam Majumder and Ben Shaby and Brian Reich and Dan Cooley},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://reetamm.github.io/BezELS/}, }

what: Bezier splines for Estimating Limit Sets
title: Bezier splines for Estimating Limit Sets
text: BezELS (Bezier splines Estimating Limit Sets) performs tail inference bivariate data unit exponential marginal distributions. package implements methodology paper arXiv.

title: Bezier splines for Estimating Limit Sets
text: can install development version BezELS GitHub :

title: Bezier splines for Estimating Limit Sets
text: following example generates data logistic copula, fits Bezier spline limit set boundary using MCMC, tail inference. ’re going plot posterior draws polar Euclidean coordinates.  Finally, let’s calculate metrics.
code: library(BezELS) set.seed(1) # Generate some data simdata             <- gen_data_exp(n = 500, theta = 0.3, tau = 0.75, copula = 'l') x                   <- simdata$x r                   <- simdata$r w                   <- simdata$w data_marg_r_0       <- simdata$data_marg_r_0 # Run MCMC to fit a bezier spline to the limit set samples  <- fit_mcmc_bezier( N = data_marg_r_0$N,                          r = data_marg_r_0$r,                          w = data_marg_r_0$w,                          r_0 = data_marg_r_0$r_0,                          iters = 1100, burn = 100,                          traceplot=F, print.every = 100) #> 1 0.54 0 0.99 0.5 0.8 0.54 0.99 0 0.52 1 // eta =  0.7801029  #> 100 0.68 0.05 0.92 0.72 0.98 0.1 1 0 0.84 2.03 // eta =  0.876082  #> 200 0.28 0 0.63 1 1 0.79 0.98 0.2 0.66 1.5 // eta =  1  #> 300 0.07 0 0.42 0.89 1 1 0.71 0.4 1 2.22 // eta =  1  #> 400 0.37 0.15 0.4 0.98 1 1 0.29 0.12 0.74 2.84 // eta =  1  #> 500 0.33 0.42 0.47 1 1 0.99 0.15 0 0.27 3.2 // eta =  1  #> 600 0.39 0.5 0.62 0.95 1 1 0.32 0 0.3 2.7 // eta =  1  #> 700 0.45 0.25 0.57 1 1 0.84 0.52 0 0 2.25 // eta =  1  #> 800 0.39 0.56 0.75 1 1 0.87 0.11 0 0.35 2.35 // eta =  1  #> 900 0.22 0.19 0.55 1 1 0.88 0.22 0.14 0.46 2.38 // eta =  1  #> 1000 0.82 0.04 0.2 0.9 1 1 0.58 0.18 0.49 2.63 // eta =  1  #> 1100 0.83 0.37 0.41 0.94 1 1 0.49 0.03 0.52 2.01 // eta =  1 samples <- samples[101:1100,] # drop the burn-in samples r_0_marg            <- simdata$r_0_marg above_thresh_marg   <- simdata$above_thresh_marg par(mfrow=c(1,2)) medcurve = plot_bezier_polar(mcmc_samples = samples, x = x, r_0_marg = r_0_marg, above_thresh_marg = above_thresh_marg,                                  copula = 'l', theta = 0.3, thin = 1, plot.fig = T, plottitle = 'Polar coordinates') plot_bezier_euclidean(mcmc_samples = samples, x = x, theta = 0.3, copula = 'l', plottitle = 'Euclidean coordinates',                           thin = 1, above_thresh_marg = above_thresh_marg, plot.truth = T, medcurve = medcurve) summary(apply(samples[,1:10], 1, eta_empirical)) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>  0.8451  1.0000  1.0000  0.9974  1.0000  1.0000 summary(samples[,11]) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>  0.8451  1.0000  1.0000  0.9974  1.0000  1.0000  omega <- seq(0.01,0.99,by = 0.01) delta <- omega lambda_omega    <- rep(NA,99) tau1_delta      <- rep(NA,99)  for(i in 1:99){     lambda_omega[i] <- median(apply(samples,1,lambda_empirical, omega = omega[i]))     tau1_delta[i]   <- median(apply(samples,1,tau_empirical, delta = delta[i])) } par(mfrow=c(1,2)) plot(omega,lambda_omega,'l', ylab = expression(lambda(omega)), xlab = expression(omega)) plot(delta,tau1_delta,'l', ylab = expression(tau[1](delta)), xlab = expression(delta))

title: Main MCMC fit function — fit_mcmc_bezier
text: function main MCMC function fit 2D Bezier spline limit set boundary bivariate data exponential margins

title: Main MCMC fit function — fit_mcmc_bezier
code: fit_mcmc_bezier(   N,   r,   w,   r_0,   priors = list(p0y_mean = 0, p0y_sd = 1, p1x_mean = 0, p1x_sd = 1, p1y_mean = 0, p1y_sd     = 1, p2x_mean = 0, p2x_sd = 1, p3_mean = 0, p3_sd = 1, p4y_mean = 0, p4y_sd = 1,     p5x_mean = 0, p5x_sd = 1, p5y_mean = 0, p5y_sd = 1, p6x_mean = 0, p6x_sd = 1,     alpha_mean = 0, alpha_sd = 1),   inits = list(p0y = qnorm(0.5), p1x = qnorm(0.01), p1y = qnorm(0.99), p2x = qnorm(0.5),     p3 = qnorm(0.8), p4y = qnorm(0.5), p5y = qnorm(0.01), p5x = qnorm(0.99), p6x =     qnorm(0.5)),   pmix = list(pmix0 = 0.1, pmix1 = 0.1, pmix2 = c(0.1, 0.1), pmix3 = 0.4),   iters = 11000,   burn = 1000,   print.every = 1000,   traceplot = T )

title: Main MCMC fit function — fit_mcmc_bezier
text: N Number data points truncated Gamma distribution fitted r Vector radii length N w Vector angles length N r_0 Vector truncation thresholds length N priors list priors inits list initial values pmix list mixture components iters Total number iterations burn Number burn-iterations print.every many iterations output traceplot Plot traceplot (TRUE/FALSE)

title: Main MCMC fit function — fit_mcmc_bezier
text: samples Matrix MCMC samples Bezier control points, shape parameter, eta

title: Main MCMC fit function — fit_mcmc_bezier

title: Plot the limit set based on MCMC output in Euclidean coordinates and export median curve — plot_bezier_euclidean
text: mcmc_samples Output object mcmc_bezier function x Original data exponential margins above_thresh_marg Vector TRUE/FALSE values, TRUE indicates points selected fitting truncated Gamma model theta True value copula dependence parameter (known) copula True parametric copula form (known) thin.Thin posterior plotting - ideally correspond thin.parameter plot_bezier_polar function medcurve Median curve output plot.bezier.polar function plottitle Title plot plot.truth TRUE/FALSE whether true limit set plotted (known)

title: Plot the limit set based on MCMC output in polar coordinates and export median curve — plot_bezier_polar
text: mcmc_samples Output object mcmc_bezier function x Original data exponential margins r_0_marg Vector truncation thresholds points above_thresh_marg Vector TRUE/FALSE values, TRUE indicates points selected fitting truncated Gamma model theta True value copula dependence parameter (known) copula True parametric copula form (known) thin.Thin posterior plotting (median curve calculation) plot.fig TRUE/FALSE whether limit set plotted plottitle Title plot (used plot.fig = T) plot.truth TRUE/FALSE whether true limit set plotted (known)
